Among the most notable are: â€¢ Qibya Massacre (1953): Israeli forces, led by Ariel Sharon, attacked the village of Qibya, destroying many homes and killing around 69 civilians, including women and children. â€¢ Kafr Qasim Massacre (1956): Occurred during the Suez Crisis when Israeli forces killed approximately 48 residents of Kafr Qasim after enforcing a curfew that the villagers had not been informed about. â€¢ Sabra and Shatila Massacre (1982): Took place in the Sabra and Shatila Palestinian refugee camps in Lebanon during the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, with militias carrying out the massacre under Israeli supervision, killing between 800 and 3,500 Palestinians. â€¢ Hebron Mosque Massacre (1994): An Israeli settler, Baruch Goldstein, opened fire on worshippers inside the Ibrahimi Mosque in Hebron, killing 29 Palestinians and injuring more than 100. â€¢ Jenin Camp Massacre (2002): During the Second Intifada, Israeli forces laid siege to Jenin Refugee Camp, killing dozens of Palestinians and destroying a large part of the camp. â€¢ Attacks on Gaza Strip (2008, 2012, 2014, 2021): Israel launched several wars on Gaza, resulting in the deaths of thousands of Palestinians, including many women and children, and extensive destruction of homes and infrastructure. â€¢ Tantura Massacre (1948): In May 1948, after occupying the village of Tantura near Haifa, Israeli forces killed hundreds of villagers, who were buried in mass graves. The exact death toll remains undetermined. â€¢ Lydda and Ramla Massacres (1948): Following the occupation of the cities of Lydda and Ramla, Israeli forces killed hundreds of civilians and forced thousands of Palestinians to march under harsh conditions, leading to numerous deaths. â€¢ Beit Daras Massacre (1948): Israeli forces attacked the village of Beit Daras, and as villagers retreated, they were bombarded, resulting in the deaths of many, including women and children, in an effort to control the village. â€¢ First Gaza Massacre (1956): During the Suez Crisis, Israel launched intense attacks on Gaza, resulting in the deaths of more than 275 Palestinians in various areas of the strip. â€¢ Rafah and Khan Yunis Massacres (1956): Following the Israeli occupation of Khan Yunis and Rafah, forces carried out mass killings, killing around 500 residents of Khan Yunis and 250 in Rafah, including many unarmed civilians. â€¢ Bahr el-Baqar School Massacre (1970): Although it occurred in Egypt, Israeli air forces bombed the Bahr el-Baqar elementary school, killing 30 children and injuring others. â€¢ Nazareth Massacre (1976): On Palestinian Land Day, Israeli forces killed six Palestinians from the Galilee and Negev regions during demonstrations against land confiscation, making Land Day a symbol of Palestinian resistance. â€¢ First Al-Aqsa Mosque Massacre (1990): Sparked when settlers attempted to lay a cornerstone for the "Third Temple" in the mosqueâ€™s courtyard, Israeli forces intervened, killing 20 Palestinians and injuring more than 150. â€¢ Askar Camp Massacre (2002): During the Second Intifada, Israel launched an attack on the Askar refugee camp near Nablus, resulting in multiple Palestinian deaths and long-term occupation of homes to suppress the uprising. â€¢ Shuja'iyya Massacre (2014): This massacre took place in the Shuja'iyya neighborhood of Gaza during Israel's war on the strip, where intensive shelling killed over 70 Palestinians, injured hundreds, and destroyed numerous buildings and homes. â€¢ Great March of Return Massacre (2018): During the Great March of Return protests along the Gaza border, Israeli forces fired on peaceful demonstrators, killing over 200 Palestinians and injuring thousands. These and other massacres remain part of a bitter and tragic history endured by the Palestinian people over decades, etched in Palestinian and Arab collective memory.

We didn't sing it anymore, my father and I, or even speak of it. After he died, it used to come back to me a lot. Being older, I began to understand the lyrics. At the beginning, it sounds like a guy is trying to get his girlfriend to secretly meet up with him at midnight. But it's an odd place for a tryst, a hanging tree, where a man was hung for murder. The murderer's lover must have had something to do with the killing, or maybe they were just going to punish her anyway, because his corpse called out for her to flee. That's weird obviously, the talking-corpse bit, but it's not until the third verse that "The Hanging Tree" begins to get unnerving. You realize the singer of the song is the dead murderer. He's still in the hanging tree. And even though he told his lover to flee, he keeps asking if she's coming to meet him. The phrase Where I told you to run, so we'd both be free is the most troubling because at first you think he's talking about when he told her to flee, presumably to safety. But then you wonder if he meant for her to run to him. To death. In the final stanza, it's clear that that's what he's waiting for. His lover, with her rope necklace, hanging dead next to him in the tree. I used to think the murderer was the creepiest guy imaginable. Now, with a couple of trips to the Hunger Games under my belt, I decide not to judge him without knowing more details. Maybe his lover was already sentenced to death and he was trying to make it easier. To let her know he'd be waiting. Or maybe he thought the place he was leaving her was really worse than death. Didn't Iwant to kill Peeta with that syringe to save him from the Capitol? Was that really my only option? Probably not, but I couldn't think of another at the time. I guess my mother thought the whole thing was too twisted for a seven-year-old, though. Especially one who made her own rope necklaces. It wasn't like hanging was something that only happened in a story. Plenty of people were executed that way in 12. You can bet she didn't want me singing it in front of my music class. She probably wouldn't like me doing it here for Pollux even Mockingjay Chapter 9

I'm a professional Folksinger, and a lot of the songs that are collected from the "folk" out in the country are very unpolished like this one when collected, and later polished up and rerecorded by professional singers. This is a totally realistic example of a Traditional song that someone might sing as it was passed down to them, complete with the raw emotion such songs often have. That's why I liked it so much. It was believable.
how do you think James Newton's background as a composer influenced this? Any comments? Loved your comment btw.

Well, you asked for  comments, so here's a lesson! First I am not personally familiar with James Newton's musical background so I can't comment on this part, but I am very familiar with songs from the Appalachians, which is the area that the story was supposed to take place in. I could hear a similarity to other songs from these mountains, so I suspect Newton did some research. There is a long tradition of unaccompanied singing that was brought over from the British Isles, particularly Scotland. The main difference is technical, as these songs are remembered orally instead of being written down or recorded, the refrain or chorus tends to remain the same instead of being changed to fit each verse. This is not something the average listener would even notice, so it was fine with me. Songs about hanging or hangmen is pretty common, there is one about "Hangman, Hangman, slack your rope awhile" in which the prisoner sees each family member in turn ( father, mother, so on) but no one will help him until his sweetheart shows up and saves him. That particular song is very old and versions exist that probably go back hundreds of years, and was brought over by the original settlers when they came.  There are different tunes, versions or "variants" as they are called, all tell pretty much the same story and can be recognized as basically the same song by Folklorists and Folksingers. So the song in the movie is on a recognized theme. Sometimes in a concert I sing different versions of the same song from different countries and times and people are often surprised to learn it's actually the same song!  Also in the story the area is very impoverished, it's unlikely that there is recorded music or even  radio available ( forget YouTube) so it's probable that people went back to the oral music tradition. Songs like this are not just for entertainment, they are also a kind of therapy to let out strong bottled up emotions, especially if your life isn't so great and you're oppressed.  The raw way Katniss sings it is completely believable and I'd have been disappointed if they had done it any other way. Folk music is often viewed kind of as an extension of the self, in the Oral tradition there would have been hundreds of songs people would have known, each one capturing a particular situation or emotion. They are very therapeutic.
@@melissapinol7279your answer is impressive. now i wanna learn more

Thank you! I was born in 1960 and my dad was a "Folkie" so I've literally been listening to and studying this stuff all my life. Some of my very first memories are of listening to folk music, my mom said I was singing Sea Shanties when I was 3 years old! When I went to college I studied Anthropology and studied a lot of Folklore, I found out even more about the Oral tradition. I would say I'm an amateur Folklorist, though I was a Counselor and a professional writer for a living. I started singing Folk music in my 20's, I used to perform for various events and did one album which is on YouTube.  If you have any specific questions about Folk music, just ask!

My family heritage is from the Smokies (so...the same, but not exactly WV Appalachians).  Same harmonies, same chord progressions.   I love how Howard had the violin played with fiddle technique here - it was BRILLIANT and brought me back to my ancestral home from centuries ago.

@@gatoesponjosoo  Appalachian-style music is actually quite easy to learn as it uses the most basic chord progressions that "regular folks" can hear, and play on whatever instruments they had or made.   The best violinists (IMO) learn both classical style playing as well as folk-style playing, and most string players will learn these simple folk songs as the building blocks of everything they do later.   Not that this is all about strings but this would have been a song accompanied by fiddle.  Having the tune expanded tastefully I thought was brilliant - both the strings and the voices intensify and multiply without veering into contemporary or classical harmonies (which would take the 'Appalachian' out of it.  I cannot get enough of Howard's music.  In anything, but especially here, in this simple piece of music.

@@melissapinol7279  I was just posting somewhere that my training is classical but my ancestry is heavy, heavy Appalachian/Native American and so studying the music that comes from Appalachian traditions is my fascination. In the first book, Katniss realizes, thanks to Peeta, that her dismissal of music comes from missing her dad. She's been resisting the raw emotion and more importantly the emotional risk that music brings with it so I think it's perfect that she's not a Broadway singer prodigy. She's a woman of action, not words. That self expression muscle in her has been actively shut down by her when she was a little girl because she realized that surviving is more important than articulating (though it is in fact a huge part of survival, which she finds out later) so yeah, she's not going to win a Tony for this. Who cares. She got something much more profound out of singing. She communicated with her dad and found the inspiration and strength she so desperately needed to keep moving forward. A genius decision.

@@williamvaughn4418 he used a jabberjay BUT he hated mockingjays as he saw them as unnatural (the Capitol's jabberjays had bred with the female mockingbirds in district 12 and thus mockingjays were born) . So to him this new mutated bird represented how the Capitol could not control everything and mockingjays themselves cant be controlled with those remotes like jabberjays can. It is great symbolism that Katniss became the mockingjay and that was the symbol of the resistance as it couldn't be controlled, and again it was something that Snow had hated since he was young.

I didn't pick up on that. The Capitol Jabberjay were all male. The District 12 Mockingbirds were all female. There is something thematic going on there. The mockingbird is a songbird. Is Corialanous the Jabberbay? He was sent to District 12 and like the Jabberjay reported back on rebels. Was he mating with the District 12 Mockingbird? Did they make a Mockingjay? Like the Jabberbay the capitol was able to control Corialanous and Lucy Gray could not be controlled.  There are 64 years between the 10th and 74th Hunger Games. Katniss is 16, meaning there were 48 years between the 10th Hunger Games and her birth. Snow says they marry young in the districts, there could be 2 generations between Lucy Gray and Katniss if Lucy Gray got pregnant and spawned a Mockingjay. I know people think it's Maude Ivory that is related to Katniss but that parallel is pretty strong. Unless its being used more loosely. @@AyeshaM02

@@04nbod thatâ€™s a very interesting take and I think youâ€™re right that Snow represents the jabberyjay whilst Lucy Gray is the mocking bird, and years later Katniss is the mockingjay. Even if this isnâ€™t interpreted literally as in Katniss being a direct descendant of them, I still love the parallels youâ€™ve drawn. And yes many people say Maude Ivory is the relation to Katniss but I wouldnâ€™t mind it being Lucy Gray. I love that Suzanne Collins has written The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes in a way that it enriches the existing lore. Even years later we find new layers and see how Snowâ€™s arc is cyclical. So many moments of this new movie link to the original HG films and we  see how Snow was watching his insecurities and unresolved issues play out in the form of Katniss.

@@williamvaughn4418 yes I see what youâ€™re saying, and youâ€™re right that they specifically had Snow use a jabberjay/ mockingjay as the method for causing Sejanusâ€™ downfall, because it mirrors how the mockingjay (Katniss) was his own downfall. Itâ€™s like a you reap what you sow situation for Snow

If only female mockingbirds existed they couldnt reproduce. They made the jabberjays male on purpose so they wouldn't be able to get knocked up. It still wound up backfiring on them. Lucy was the songbird (Mockingbird) and Snow was the Jabberjay, though they both had snake elements to them. Through them they created a mockingjay. A creature that wasnt supposed to exist but thrived in district 12.

@grantscarsdale2997Â  I haven't listened to mainstream music in decades so this comment is just laughable. A beautiful singing voice, one that makes the birds fall silent, is how Katniss' voice is described in the books. The text book definition of a beautiful singing voice is characterized by a warm rich tone that is smooth, resonant and pleasing to the ear. It has a range that can effortlessly navigate through different registers from deep lows to soaring highs. The vocal control is precise in pitch, dynamics and phrasing which allows the singer to convey nuances in the music such as expression of emotions of joy, or longing. It always has an artfully controlled vibrato that adds warmth and richness which enhances the beauty without overpowering the melody.  I never stated Jennifer Lawrence had a bad voice. She can stay on pitch for the most part, however she does not have any of those characteristics that I previously mentioned. To say otherwise is denying reality. I'm not sure why people like you are so far stuck up these celebrities butts that any portrayal of them has to be overflowing with only positive, glowing comments. So much that when I don't tow the line you verbally attack my character.  Therefore for you to tell me "nature abhors fakeness" and to "expand your horizons of what music means" while denying the realities of what objectively qualifies someone to be labeled as having a beautiful singing voice is just poetic irony.

I never read the books, though I am an avid Sci-Fi/Fantasy fan.    There are a few books I put down just partway through.   Films.  THE HUNGER GAMES is a story I put down and never went back to for cause.   I simply disagree absolutely with the script writers view of WHAT Humanity IS and what Humanity's response is to the sort of misery being dealt out in the story.   No human I know will kneel to that.   Rather than watching me endure that, you would be killing me.   So, to ME, it is a preposterous story.   I gave the 3 BluRay disks I'd bought to my sister.  That Is All.

If there were new books and movies, I'd imagine it like this. Katniss dies, and the world mourns her, but a new faction enters now that Katniss is gone, and her influence is gone. And they take over leaving Katniss is children to take charge, but then they die, leaving the world in mayhem. And eventually all districts are just as bad as district 13. Years past until Katniss wakes up not in the districts but in an unknown land a land of nobody a land in which nature flourishes she thinks it's a nightmare of her past hunger games, but it sure isn't it's real there are other people men and women and a big pile of weapons, supplies and others in the middle, and then she sees her sister or does she? She is hallucinating and confused, she fights and when it's the last two it's her and her dead sister. The capitol calls that the games are over, but Katniss can't hear, she's in a different mind space, and they witness her shooting at nothing. Then the world slowly crumbles and Katniss truly wakes up from a horrid dream she is awakened in the world nothing is there nothing at all! She is covered in sand and can barely breathe, she runs to many hidden places, revealing the events leading up to the great war before and the history of her world and how she can save it. A figure then appears a man not peter but the President he greets Katniss, and she freaks out crying and saying "I thought you got killed!", He replies" I never did you'd think you and your peasants can kill me?", "all you are is a poor woman". Katniss bows him right in the heart she notices that the blood is changing his skin and reveals the man the myth the legend Peeta!  He apologises before dying in her arms, she vows to murder whoever done it and finds clues left behind by whoever made Katniss is world well her world! Eventually, she takes a boat to this small island, signing a new song. Here's a short snippet "Peeta, would beg to see this earth heal, excel not descend, to this end. And for me, not to see, none of my friends here by me, makes me plead for mercy!" Yes, I know it's shitty, but this isn't a hunger game movie/ book without a song Then she lands at a place when she steps foot on the sand the floor disappears and reveals it was all an illusion, and it was truly a waterfall she enters a place filled with deadly creatures ready to kill, and she gets pounced at ready to die, but then the movie ends ready for the next!

@@JabamiLain No problem,i will answer. I'm 39 years old. I tell my life experience. It will be long :) to see the whole picture. I cant answer with a few word.  I grow up in a heavy loaded family. Do you know that feeling,when you in something(family,relationship,school,the street,with friends,at work,...or the system with a higher view),and you think...this is "normal". Ofcourse its normal,cuz everybody doing it. And you dont have questions,none.Why would you have?Its everything in order....just i dont find my self in it. I want to be useful,reasoned - but with my death....its sick.I know. But i got this feedback from my family,and from everywhere. Why? This is my legacy from my family.I am always the last.I doesnt exist. I cant roar so loud,to my family hear me.Its sad. So before my 33 birthday,i have a plan.I want to die at 40,cuz there is nothing after 40...(sick thinking) - with a useful death...i save somebody,and i die...something like this...which i see in movies.  :)  In a sick family - i grow up sick. But where is the twist?I am now 39 and i dont want to die at 40.I dont want to die at all :) And the 180 degree is i want to be useful,reasoned with my ...life :) We find each oders with my darling,when i was 33.I dont have any relationship to this time. But im glad.I got many embarrassing,shameful situation. At this time,was my first light in my life. I see things differently.Why? Cuz i got positive feedback.And that way,i can compare. Ohhh yes,the question - how do i know?... My life experience is,the honest people is talking about his/herself.Even if he/she has mistakes - and talks about it.Not polishing the story.And responsible.Makes example,at least trys. And what i see today? Everybody is perfect.Try to make me,look like - the problem is always with me...sure. If i die,the world will be a better place...nope. "If everybody just do his/her own part,the world will be a better place". - Gandhi There is another question. - How do i know what is right,and what is wrong? I try to know my self.Selfknowlidge - i have a lot of fails,mistakes. What gives them away? - i learn psychology autodidact.Just very very rookie :) - but i understand roles.Roles like in a family. What i will take with me to the life(jobinterview,to the job,to the relationship, friendship,...conversations,and whatever i go - they come with me,they are my parts). There is good in bad thing - like learning from it. And i see that not just my family is sick. Its very rare to see a healthy family - like whom live in peace,honesty(they act like what they say),and love(free,supporting eachothers for nothing,just cuz i want to support,no need to explain :)) You know what...i know its a hard for living.But if i can support ...or i can make conversation with somebody who write about hisself,im happy. Ohh and one more thing - what gives them away? - if we speak to eachother :)

@@kareszjako5497 my family is a bit sick too, not to the point of having lack of confidence (because my mom always worked in my confidence in a good way) or having suicidal thoughts, but to the point that I am sick and tired of being here at home. *!SPOILER ALERT!* FOR The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes. THIS WAS MADE BY GOLDEN HAMBURGER! I would just like to say that I have a theory. Lucy Gray Baird lived after Coriolanus shot in the woods. She may have even been Katniss's grandmother. Lucy created the song for Coriolanus Snow and was probably the only one that had knew about it. There was a chance that she could have told someone in the covey, or somewhere else, but I doubt it. She had died, how would anyone else know the song. There could be a Mockingjay that repeated it, but I doubt people would really hear it. She would have had to live in disguise too. Although, if she lived she could have passed it down to close friends. She could also pass it down to her daughter if she had one. The daughter or her close friends could pass it down too. Somebody had to tell her the song. If it was Katniss's mom, my theory might be right. If you have any ideas feel free to tell me. Remember, this is just a theory btw.

I love this song. I've only read the books and have not seen the movies but after reading The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes I looked it up to see what tune the moviemakers came up with. I think this is perfect! This song:   (*Spoilers for the series*) 1. Was written by Lucy Gray Baird after she witnessed the hanging of Arlo Chance in District 12. He was convicted for the murders of three men and before he was executed, he called out to his lover, Lil, telling her to run. Later, Lil was caught and hung alongside Sejanus Plinth, whom Coriolanus Snow betrayed. 2. Is also about Billy Taupe telling Lucy Gray that if he is going to hang, she must hang with him. However, before he could kill her, he was shot dead by Spruce. 3. Was used by Lucy Gray to send a message to Coriolanus about the place where they were to meet the next morning to escape to the North together. 4. Was banned right after Lucy Gray sang it for the first time because of its controversial lyrics. 5. Was (presumably secretly) passed down through generations until it reached Katniss Everdeen, who heard it from her father. 6. Is used by Katniss in a propaganda video to inspire rebels during the second rebellion.

A letter to all those looking for a Mockingjay: Allow me to lead our generation towards a new day of equality. The older generations have refused to give us the power given to them, so now we are taking it. If the older generations wonâ€™t step aside and make way for progress, they no longer have a seat at the table. They need to realize that we arenâ€™t children anymore, and we will take control one way or another. They can either give us a seat at the table or we will take one by force. Itâ€™s up to them. They decided their fate the moment they decided to ignore us. If they ignore our ideas, we ignore theirs. Thereâ€™s a difference between â€˜respectâ€™ and respect. Respect can mean treating someone like an authority, or it can mean treating someone like a person. When older people say â€˜if you donâ€™t respect me, I wonâ€™t respect youâ€™, what they mean is, â€˜if you donâ€™t treat me like an authority, I wonâ€™t treat you like a personâ€™. Thatâ€™s exactly what theyâ€™ve done. Theyâ€™ve stopped treating us like people because we wonâ€™t lick their boot. So now we need to stop acting like theyâ€™re an authority with any power over us. If they have no authority, they canâ€™t stop us. They need to realize the different types of respect before itâ€™s too late. We would love for them to have a seat at the table, but if it comes down to choosing our rights or their values, I will burn their seat at the table before giving up on my new family.  They canâ€™t control us anymore. We donâ€™t fear them. They donâ€™t need to fear us, but if they continue to ignore us, they will. This wonâ€™t end easily, but itâ€™ll be worth anything that happens. We will succeed, we will win, and we will have a voice. They canâ€™t stop us anymore. Iâ€™ll die before I let our generation be trampled any longer. I will do everything in my power to be seen as an equal to older generations. And if that comes peacefully, great. If it doesnâ€™t, thatâ€™s their fault. We will use violence if they refuse to step aside, but weâ€™d rather march with them than over them.  They canâ€™t see the flaws engraved into their psyche. Their policies are marred by prejudice and manipulation. Capitalism is inherently flawed and is bound to fail. Itâ€™s only still hanging on because people are scared of change. It will fall, we just need to push it. We need a democratic socialist society. Abolish the electoral college, give employees true democratic power in the workplace, etc. You canâ€™t be â€˜for the peopleâ€˜ if the only people youâ€™re for are the ones with power. Those arenâ€™t â€˜the peopleâ€™, those are the figureheads. Not all of Britain looks like the queen. The figureheads are not an accurate reflection of any society. Figureheads are the best of the best and in no way represent the working class. And yet they are the only ones with true power over the working classâ€™s rights.  We are not being represented, we are being repressed. Weâ€™re told that if they got their money, we can too. But they donâ€™t acknowledge the corruption, bribery, and privilege that gave it too them. We are not all in the same boat, weâ€™re just sailing the same sea, weathering the same storm. Some of us are on cruise ships, while others are out at sea in nothing but a life vest. We need to make sure that cruise ship becomes the titanic. This cannot be allowed to continue. We need equality. Just because weâ€™re in the same sea does not mean we all have the same opportunities to survive at sea. We need to tear down that cruise ship to create life boats. The cruise ship has more that enough material to save everyone if we give up our indoor swimming pool and basketball courts. We need to take apart the cruise ship to save everyoneâ€™s lives. And that means relinquishing a few luxuries in the process. But if a society is demolished by giving everyone a fair chance, that society has no right to exist. It should not be enough that a few people have all the luxuries.  The minimum wage cannot buy a two bedroom apartment anywhere in the US. We are on the way towards the average person not being able to afford bread. And the French can tell us how that goes. A revolution is inevitable, we just need someone to instigate it. We need a spark. And now this group is the spark. We can burn capitalism to the ground, but only if we keep moving. We have to keep fighting, no matter the cost. If you get hurt, hurt them back. You get killed, walk it off. We have to win. Thereâ€™s no other option. We cannot afford to give up. This is bigger than us. Weâ€™re fighting for the rights of an entire nation. We canâ€™t back down now. Weâ€™ll seize the day, and weâ€™ll seize it by the fucking throat if we have to.  Weâ€™re fighting for those who canâ€™t fight. Weâ€™re fighting for ourselves, for our family, and for our future. Weâ€™re fighting to form a nation. And we wonâ€™t stop now. We are fighting to create a world for nobody to be scared of just existing. Weâ€™re going to fight to the last breath if we have to, but that breath will be taken in a free nation. Loosing isnâ€™t an option, itâ€™s a death sentence. A death sentence not just to ourselves; but to every person that can't fight for themselves and every future generation. The only way Iâ€™ll die is as a martyr. I wonâ€™t die a coward. Iâ€™ll die fighting for everyone who canâ€™t fight. Iâ€™ll die fighting for everything I believe in. Iâ€™ll die fighting to make a better world for my kids. Iâ€™ll die fighting for my rights. But I wonâ€™t die without changing the world. Iâ€™ll create a revolution, or die trying.  We will fight to win, not to change. And we will win. Thereâ€™s no other option. We have to win to avenge all those who pointlessly lost their lives. We will avenge them and create a better world in their honour. They wonâ€™t die in vain. They canâ€™t. We will avenge every single sibling. Every single missing and murdered indigenous woman in northern canada. Every black person shot by a cop for no reason. Every LGBT person kicked out a killed for their existence. Every abuse victim NONE OF THEM can have died in vain. If they died in vain, I lived in vain. They did not die for nothing. And we donâ€™t fight for nothing. We fight for everything we hold dear. We fight for the martyrs. We fight for those we lost to abuse. We fight for those lost to suicide. We fight for those lost to homeless. We fight for those lost to shootings. We fight for those lost to our corrupt â€˜justiceâ€™ system, where the only justice given is to those who are rich, white and straight. We fight for those who donâ€™t have a voice. We fight to give a megaphone to those who have been silenced. We fight to give a home to those who have been forced out. We fight to give a family to those who have none left. We fight to give love to those who have lost hope. We fight to make a better world for those who don't feel like it can ever exist. We fight for the future and the past. We fight for ourselves. We fight for the weak. We fight for the silent. We fight for the abused. We fight for those who are afraid to speak out. We fight for the children that didn't choose to join a society that just puts them down. We fight for the powerless. We fight for the misfits. We fight for those who canâ€™t fight for themselves. We fight to correct the corrupt government that can no longer support the people it claims to support. It is our duty as citizens and it is our right to remove those corrupt in power and replace them with people that have our best interests in mind! People who will fight to correct what is wrong. We fight for the people. We fight to win.  It's time to fight back. No more death to those who did nothing but exist in a world that doesn't care for them. Show that WE CARE and that we will stand up for those who felt like they had no one, that the system tries to convince have no one. NOW is the time to fight! We will find those who have been silenced and give them a voice. Find those who have been abused and give them power. We fight against abusers. We fight against cops. We fight against the rich. We fight against classism. We fight against the corrupt. We fight against those who have silenced others for the colour of their skin, or who they love, or who they ARE. We fight against silence. It is time to fight back against our oppressors. We will rise with our siblings on a new day where no one is afraid to be themselves. We will make our voices heard. We will rise against those who refuse to acknowledge our existence. We will rise and live as free people. We will not surrender. Surrender is no longer an option. We cannot back down.  We will rise with the sun on a new day marked with love and acceptance, not hate and corruption behind the guise of protection. Protection without freedom is tyranny. Everyone will be heard. Everyone will be valued. The government has a choice to make. Respect our existence or expect our resistance!

@@angela_aubrams ğŸ™‚ Also, I am not strongly for this theory (Lucy Gray cared a lot about her appearance and I do not remember Sae, but I imagine her differently - because of the appearance, actually more like Coin / Coin mother), but I do not exclude that it may turn out to be real.  Sae knew how to cook a lot of strange products - maybe she had to learn it during her escape. She was the one who started the District 12 fundraiser for Katniss and Peeta in the arena.  Sae had also attended important District 13 headquarters meeting and Katniss had no idea why (but in my opinion she was there because people who knew Katniss well had to appear at the meeting, because it was about propaganda strategies). She was visiting Katniss with her grandchildren, so she was at an age Lucy Gray could be. The Hunger Games:Part 2 exist?

Pretty music. A simple tune calling out to have people join her in fighting and in death, essentially. The vocals and lyrics are deceptively fast, but delivered in a fairly flat voice. The underlying strings and brass is slow, long notes. The whole is a crescendo from one person a capella to a full orchestra and choir blasting away. You can't escape the sadness of the minor key. While it pivots around a 'necklass of hope', you can hear in the music you're for the 'rope', but it's okay. Excellently orchestrated, easily best on any of these four soundtracks.

And now,for a little grim historical background of this song that is being favorited by so many people who may or may not be completely aware of its dark history. The Original title and name of this song was called the "Song of the Rope",but the Game Master of the Hunger Games changed it to the "Song of Hope"! This is actually a song of Death" and it celebrates the death of a certain group of oppressed people who were hung in trees for the entertainment of the Americans as well as the British who relished in the murders of these people and turned them into the Hunger Games! Before some of you develop misplaced as well as uncalculated anger.....Please allow me to explain....These people have always been an oppressed people who were dis-shoveled into ghettos and projects which were then filled up with drugs in order to form a dependency which was then cultivated into violence, and warfare among them causing them to kill one another. The original Architects of this undesirable Construct were the founders and designers of these games! As a matter of fact, this very societal construct was built upon the premise of the GAMES,which were actually a Game of Death which the architects thought would be both profitable and entertaining. They sought to make sport of a certain group of people who were extremely poor, dis-advantaged and destitute! They would first make sport of them before they were murdered,while inviting and announcing to the entire community to come and watch the grisly affair which was about to take place in their town. They would EXCITEDLY ask one another...Are you coming to the Hanging TREE???...  The people then would come from all parts and gather from miles around to witness this wicked deed,bringing with them their wives, and their sons and daughters! They then would castrate the helpless victim and set him on fire while he hung from the tree and It would then be written up in the town newspaper.  When this thing was finally made illegal ,the Architects of the GAMES were so angry that they sought another way to make sport of these people so they could continue the GAMES in order to be entertained by them. They decided to hold a draft from each of these poor and downtrodden Black districts in order put to them back into the GAMES! They would offer them food and prize money contracts in order to encourage them to participate in the GAMES so they could feed and house their poor families. They would even give them a contract and assign them to a team and give them a jersey or uniform with a number on it. They did these things in order to foster a sense of brotherhood with the teams so they could create for them an artificial family from whom they would receive all their love and camaraderie. The Architects and the Owners did this because they knew they would become LOYAL to the TEAMS and thereby become dedicated to the GAMES! Thru this they would control the players and would inevitably decide the fate of these gladiators,while simultaneously prospering greatly by their continued drafting of these people into their GAMES. They would even place bets on them and decide weather or not to trade them based on their own performances and if they caused the team WIN or LOSS.  The  most unfortunate fact of the matter is...The OWNERS WOULD ALL BE WINNERS while the players would all be LOSERS! Nowadays, instead of HANGING the player of the GAMES from the trees when they have worn out their usefulness,they do things a little different. Now when a player or gladiator has worn out his usefulness,but he has made his owners a sufficient enough MONEY then they will hold a public ceremony inviting EVERYONE to come and watch the players jersey be hung in EFFIGY from a TREE!..The title should be ostensibly changed to... how "To Kill a Mocking Bird".....That's all...Shalom

I wrote this for the song. Hope y'all like it. The Hanging Tree Mississippi 1851, a decade before the U.S Civil War would begin, plantations were scattered across the entire state. Slaves working the fields had become a very common sight at the time. Two of the larger cotton plantations in the Delta sat one beside the other. Both were slave plantations but the larger of the two had nearly twice the number of slaves working the fields.  As far as plantations went, these neighboring cotton farms were as modern as any might have been. Offering freedom to slaves that worked out ten years in the cotton, they could leave or stay after ten years. The slaves were even living in share cropper type homes built on both farms. Black women didn't work the cotton fields, they worked in the big houses on plantations, raising the gardens, cooking all the food and raising the children.  On the smaller of the two farms the owner was a widower and had only the one son. The plantation master was almost constantly away on business after losing his wife. Leaving the eight year old boy to be raised by nannies. The same ladies who worked in the big house.  The farm next door was ran by an older couple whose own children had long since moved to Biloxi. But the farm's slaves had more than a dozen children. One was a girl about seven years old.  The Hanging Tree tells the ending of a story, a story about an only son of a plantation owner, a young white boy, meeting the prettiest little black girl in all of Mississippi; and neither of them ever being the same again.  The two kids had been warned against playing together or even associating but neither understood or cared about why. Eventually finding out about his son and his young live, the boy's father told him he'd forget about the girl and one day marry a white woman and inherit the cotton plantation.  But they were nearly inseparable growing up, and having gotten older, the two began realizing for them to ever be together they'd have to flee Mississippi. Planning on leaving the country if they had too and find a way to be married. The boy had reached the age of fourteen, and his 'Juliet' was herself thirteen, when rumors of the two's relationship had spread across the county and beyond.  In that place, just years before the war of North and South, it wasn't long before threats were made. Directed towards the slaves living and working on both plantations, the two teens decided to pack what little they could take and meet at midnight at the fork of the main road near the hanging tree. A meeting spot they'd used for years setting opposite of the road away from the corn and cotton fields. As fate would have it, seven riders had been traveling the main roads late at night. Three of them worked the largest of the two farms for the older plantation owners. And after hearing rumors that the star crossed teenagers were planning to run off together, the men made plans on catching them.  Although only fourteen years old, the son of the neighboring plantation owner was a crack shot with a rifle, and never left home without it. He came upon the group of riders under the full moon. Seeing three of them riding in the corn field, circling the young girl, cursing her and yelling with lassos being thrown down a round her. In an instant the boy 'referred to as a man in the song' stepped out into the open firing three shots from his rifle, instantly killing the three riders who were attempting to chase or run down the girl he loved.  He tried to get to her and escape into the corn, but the four riders that were holding back quickly captured the lad. With no loyalties to either plantation decided he'd be hanged, right there in the oldest hanging tree in all of the Mississippi Delta.  Being far enough from the road and watching the lynching unfold from the edge of the corn field, the young girl's escape was guaranteed but she was frozen to spot. In the moonlight, the young lady could see one of the dead rider's rifle shining up from the trampled corn. The boy yelled for her to run, knowing part of him at least could be free if she lived; but she never considered it. She knew for both of them to be free, it'd have to be in death "wearing a necklace of hope, side by side".  Having never used a gun in her life, she picked it up and chose her own fate right then. "Strange things did happen there", seven years of meetings between sweethearts, the murder of three, and another was the threat of death being nothing compared to what two of Mississippi's children meant to each other.

Toning down the brutality of the books in the movies is one thing. But why did they have to turn "wear a necklace of rope" into "wear of necklace of hope" is beyond me. "Necklace of rope" has such a deep meaning in the books, far deeper that it would imply at first glance. The movie simply does an injustice to the song. Her voice will always remind me of the books, though. Haunting.

I mean technically "necklace of hope" can be just as deep/metaphorical as "necklace of rope". Because hope can kill/strangle you as well (as we've seen several times in the movies). But in general I'd agree with you, the song in the books is more impactful.  I think it's pretty safe to say, that i a way (as it is the case with many other films on books) the books will always be better than the movies. (Quite simply for the fact that more things are left up for imagination in books)

But in the movie, the Capitol explains that they changed the lyrics from rope to hope, to give the people hope. For the media to literally change a scene and make a scene about changing a scene to give hope IS RIDICULOUSLY AMAZING.

The entire premise of the song in the book is so good. They messed up by changing it. It took me a while to figure out, but the song is about a murderer who is telling his lover to flee from life, flee from all others. To kill themself so they could be together forever.

I remember getting goosebumps by that scene. It was such a unique, poweful moment. Not that it moved me to tears, but it was just indescribable. The scene was so simple, yet it was so epic and pure. For a moment,  it was like being part of the world and you were about to join the resistance. And Jennifer Lawrence's unaltered voice really added to the required mood. I was simply blown away. The remix on the other hand is a total blasphemy. It reduces a beautiful song to a throwaway dance mix. Autotuning Jennifer Lawrence's voice for that was the biggest insult.

Not really. The one who started revolution was Rue. She was the real sinsajo. Why? you may ask. Ok. She was the one who broke the unspoken rule of not making teams with different districts. She was the one who went against the system. Then Katniss just followed. But the first trully rebel was Rue.  What Pretty Little Liars says its true. She compared to the rest of the country, basically, was small. I'm not saying she wasn't important. She was to the rest of the people like a focal point for a ballerina. This people has been suffering a lot for so long but didn't say/do anything until they got Katniss. Her role was to give spirits, strength and hope. People may be angry and even have decided to do something about it, but they wont if they don't have the feeling that they are supported. They needed to know they weren't the only ones.  And that feeling, if you ask me, knowing that there's someone telling you to keep on it makes you cry and rise up. And you walk out the streets and do what you need to fight against the criminals that are profaning the sacred place of the presidency, make them pay for all the deaths and start to heal and make your country a better place.  Now, coming back to Katniss. As I said her role big, but small compared to what the other people did.

It's interesting. I've seen many people here have been touched by this piece of music emotionally in some way or another. However, I have not seen many credit the reason for this emotional connection. I've seen people, rightfully, commend Lawrence's voice and the majesty of the scene this music evokes. However, I have neither seen nor heard any mention of James Newton Howard. This man put me close to tears with his score of King Kong. He put me through a whirlwind of emotions in the first and second hunger games films. He caught my imagination for his work in the film Blood Diamond. He is the only reason I waded through Snow White and the Huntsman, and I will always remember his partnership with Zimmer for the Dark Knight. Film Music composers are the unsung heroes of film. This scene is impactful for one reason alone to me. His subtle early introduction of the violin accompaniment. His gradual swell of horns, the use of soprano singers, added to the horns at the song's conclusion add a haunting tone to the reflective cellos and violins that have developed, altered and enhanced the melody to it's limit. The change from quiet to loud, the seamless transition from soloist to choir to instruments. Howard is a master at his trade. His manipulation of the melody and use of instruments and voices is what causes you to feel sorrow and reflection upon hearing the music. The lyrics are good. However, it is the music that is genius. Everyone here has praised Lawrence. However, I see few praising the maker of your true emotional response. Lawrence sang, Howard composed. Lawrence may have made the melody, but a melody alone is not strong enough to make someone cry or laugh or shout in anger or triumph. True music needs accompaniment, instruments and the manipulation of the melody you know and love. Howard delivers in ways none of you even notice. Howard is an unsung hero, just like Hans Zimmer, Howard Shore, Harry Gregson Williams, John Williams, the late James Horner and so many others. This piece speaks to me, but only because of James Newton Howard. All I ask of you, if you have made it this far down my wall of text, is to credit him and thank him for his majestic masterpiece here, in equal measure to Lawrence, because he is the one to me who needs this acknowledgement most. He is the one who can replicate the emotions we have felt with this piece. His composition is what we love. Songs aren't just about lyrics or melody. They are about the whole thing. The instruments, the accompaniment, the harmony, and how these all come together to create something special. Cheers to you James Newton Howard. You've done it again ;)

Billy Brooke, Lawrence didn't make the melody, though. It was done by Jeremiah Fraites and Wesley Schultz of The Lumineers. Jennifer Lawrence sang, and like you said, James Newton Howard composed. Anyway, orchestral film scores are my favorite kinds of music. So I agree with what you said.

The best, most epic scene from Mockingjay part I. Why, oh, why did Lionsgate cut the budget for Mockingjay II? It was unmoving and flat, when it could have been like Catching Fire or Mockingjay part I. No one was half as believable as in Mockingjay Part I (except for Josh, who was great). I can't believe they finished in such a low note of a movie when they had a cult saga in the making.

I loved Mockingjay: Part 2. A fitting end to a great franchise. But I do agree that The Hanging Tree is by far the best moment in the whole series. When they play it over the attack on the dam, it is truly epic and moving. As I am only 13 years old, when I look back on my earlier years in the future, one of the main movies I will think of is The Hunger Games series. Jennifer Lawrence is an amazing actress, a beautiful woman, a complete badass, and surprisingly has a great voice. Also, I am not ashamed to admit, she is my main celebrity crush. These films may not be perfect, but I love them anyway, for their future nostalgia and their grand, epic scale. Long live Katniss Everdeen.

This song was sung to Katniss by her father before he died in the coal mine explosion. Even though Katniss's mother warned her about not singing it, she keeps it dear to her heart. In the scene in the movie, it was showing the rebellion of the districts. All the people (in the climbing trees scene) tricked the Capital's Peace Keepers, and went against what they said. In the water/dam scene, It was showing how the people of District 6 blew up the dam, to turn out the electricity of the Capital, since the capital used water energy. Hope this helps!

There are 3 key points that I'd like to bring up 1. If one would bother doing some research, they'd know that Jennifer Lawrence has very little skill in singing. In an interview with David Letterman, she described herself as a â€œa tone-deaf Amy Winehouse.â€  2. For those arguing AGAINST autotune, it's not as if autotune is used only to make someone sound perfect. It usually is, though going hand-in-hand with that, they must make sure that they keep the pitch. That's what they seem to do in this song. Otherwise, they purposely alter the song to make it fit the storyline better. Katniss is an amateur singer with some talent, but not very much. This could easily imply that she has pitch, but little else. Another point stemming from this is that if they released the song with her going flat and sharp every other note, would people enjoy it? It'd actually sound drastically different, especially during the transition from acapella to with music. The incorrect notes would be identified far more easily.  3. Even if it was completely natural, she is nowhere near being a great singer. I'd applaud her ability to keep pitch, but that's nowhere near what it means to sing. Breath control, diction. If one doesn't breathe at the right times, it sounds choppy, and it easily causes you to flat your notes. If you don't control your breathing well, your words don't sound as well either. One could say that I am a critic, and I do seem to have more qualification in saying whether she is or isn't a "good singer," so to speak, as I do study vocal music. As an example, if she went somewhere like a choir districts competition, she'd more than likely get a 3, which is not that good at all. A 1 gets you a medal, and you go to state, like I did.  In conclusion, if that were her natural voice, no editing, minus sound balancing in order to make sure every part is heard, she'd have plenty of potential that just needs to be trained, but the reality of the matter is that not many care for the voice of a tone-deaf Amy Winehouse.

i dunno why people overreact to this comment... or discussion... or critique. He might not word it nicely, but his points sounded valid, and in the end, he never said that J-lawrence is a terrible singer, and in a way complimented her for her (possible) talent in singing. It's just that she might not train herself in singing since acting is her primary career. At the end of the day most people wont judge J-lawrence in singing anyway, and this comment was quite educative.

Nat BreenÂ I made my comment because there are plenty of people out there who remain uneducated and honestly believe she has an amazing talent of singing, when she does not. It was never an attempt at self-promotion. What is there to gain from my comment? Likes? Subscribers? Is it supposed to make me feel better about myself in any way? It has absolutely no effect on my image on youtube, nor does it affect my opinion of myself. Also, maybe you ought to be rereading my initial comment. I didn't critique her actual abilities. The closest I came to doing so was with my third point. In such, I just stated more legitimate facts. I went so far as to say that if that were her natural voice, without editing, she'd definitely have a lot of potential. That was the closest I got to critiquing her actual voice. No, it was not necessary, however, having an opinion, one way or the other, is not necessary either. Regardless, speaking in an informative manner for everyone's sake seems to have worked fairly well, as far as I am concerned.Â

Dude, I wasn't critiquing you at all. I don't know anything at all about music or singing, I was simply asking why you felt it necessary to make your comment given that it was entirely unnecessary and unwanted.

I never said anything about you critiquing me. No one said it was unwanted until after the fact. On the flip side, your comment was unnecessary, and your negative attitude was inherently unwanted. Personally, no, Lawrence doesn't have the best singing voice, but neither do I, and when it comes to a folk song like this (a folk song in that fictional universe anyway) I still prefer a 'real' sounding voice singing it, instead of something perfected in a studio.  It feels more real, and like it has real meaning, something anyone would sing to make themselves feel better, or like in the bombing scene in the movie, gear themselves up for war.  Not a pretty tune sung on stage to the masses.  Not that I don't like that kind of music, but for this, I'm glad Lawrence sang it, and even though it seems they may have fiddled with her voice a bit to make it sound 'better' I'd still listen to this version more than a hundred 'perfected' versions.

+William Essex  Okay way do you think that Ill hear you out

+RegentofSparta Well the story has been done before as every Battle Royale fan will tell you. The characters are not particularly compelling. They're all very serious but also very dull. There's no flair to the writing. the only character I really enjoyed was Philip Seymour Hoffman's and I think that's mostly due to his talent as an actor than his writing. It revolves around Katniss. Which would be fine if she was a good character. I much preferred Lawrence in X-Men because as good an actress I'm sure she is, her character writing is just lacklustre in these films. Furthermore the whole 'bleak dystopian future' thing is very done. If it was more brutal it would be better but it's just Dystopia Light. I want full fat Dystopia.

There are subtle differences though are there not between Battle Royale and Hunger Games? Anyway I will agree on the fact that more brutalness would get its point across - however its hampered by the 12 certificate there are several scenes where I think they could really have tuned it up (two really good examples are the carnage in district 12 and the story Finnick tells in a rebel broadcast about sexual exploitation ) Disagree on characters though but oh well.

+William Essex I've watched both (BR and HG) and even if similar, the feeling is different (at least to me). Probably the movies are not the cup of tea of everybody, and that's  okay :) Personally I loved the books better, they are much more detailed and you can get way more into the characters.

Prim died to show that although we may think our family is safe, their life can be taken unexpectedly. Coin died because she wasn't who everyone thought she was. She was the districts version of Snow. All she wanted was to use Katniss so bring her power. Anyway, Katniss couldn't react to Prim's death; in the book the bombing was very unexpected and when Katniss got up to help those kids she noticed medics rushing in from D13. Katniss described herself as the girl who was now on fire with no sister... then blacks out. she couldn't react.

Annabeth Chase or reading

While reading the books a few years ago, Finnick was my favourite character, was heartbroken and disappointed when he died like he did... And it was painful to watch that part of the movie when it came out... Cause I knew that fateful moment would come... And it did, sadly... Made me feel like crap again... Prim's death was surprising to say the least in the books, and sad too, but less in the movies for me as I knew it was coming (and was trying my best not to tell it to the friends I was watching it with who didn't read the book lol)... The last book isn't the best in my opinion, because of the sadness, the pain and the psychological torture they're all going through (and Finnick's death, seriously Suzanne that's not cool), but I guess it's just like a real war/revolution... Not fun... It was a mature book, sad and painful, but mature and interesting... I still love that after Prim's death that was like the trigger for her mental breakdown after all she's been through, after her talk with snow, during Coin's speech, she's like... "Why the f*** should I keep listening to your bs, you've taken everything from me, so now just shut up, f*** you" and shoots that arrow in her face, goes "f*** this, I'm out" and goes living with Peeta who's the symbol of the quiet life she now aspires to live, with someone who shares her pain and traumatizing experiences...

Well, this is my interpretation of the song. It may not be correct, but i am also writing this to discuss with other people and see what they think the song means. Some things i will state may be considered a given by some, but i would not feel good if i left them out. Sorry for the length of my comment... Â  ~At first the singer is like an observer to what happens. This can be identified by the use third person ("he murdered","he called out"). Later, first person is used and it's revealed the singer is the dead man. ~The audience is in my opinion the man's loved one. About the singer and its audience, i will say more later... ~It seems to me that the Hanging Tree is every place that people get hurt or even die while fighting against the Capitol. It could mean the whipping posts or execution stands but i think it's mostly about the rebellion (first or second?). Personally, i think the last four lines of each verse are reinforcing my opinion. "Strange things did happen here. No stranger would it be. If we met at midnight. In the hanging tree." Stranger things are the tortures and murders done by the Capitol. It wouldn't be stranger if the people turned against the Capitol and murdered some Peacekeepers too. ~By saying "Are you coming to the tree?", the singer invites its audience to come to the Tree. So, because the Tree is the rebellion, the dead man is every person that has stood against the Capitol. It makes more sense if we consider that every person that goes against the Capitol puts its life in danger (and is fully aware of it), so it is an already dead man. The loved one is every other person in the world that hasn't taken part in the rebellion (yet). Why loved one? I think it's a way to show the love among the districts' citizens. Each two of them are united, like two lovers, not just two ordinary people, but a couple with common needs, desires and goals. ~Midnight is the darkest time of a day (night actually...). It is also the time that most terrifying things (ghosts and such) are coming alive and a rebellion is terrifying for President Snow and its consequences would be dark for him. Last but not least, at midnight the day ends and a new one is coming, so if the lovers-citizens met they could bring an end to this dark era-day and give rise to a new era of peace and prosperity for everyone. The above are about the lyrics repeated in every verse. Now let me tell you my opinion about the rest. ~"Where they strung up a man. They say murdered three." So it's obvious the Capitol has killed a rebel. I can't but focus on "they say". The man probably hasn't done anything or at least anything against someone non-Capitol. He is accused of false things. The song indicates the rulers of Panem are killing innocent people. ~"Where the dead man. Called out for his love to flee." Most people would say that the dead man tried to save his loved one, telling her to run away. I will go against this and say that he tried to save her, by telling her to join the rebellion. This is the only way for her (remember the loved one is actually everyone!) to be saved. If she run away she would simply survive, but if she fought she would LIVE!!! ~"Where i told you to run. So we 'd both be free." It is just like the two lines i analyzed above, so please allow me to rest a little bit... ~"Wear a necklace of rope. Side by side with me." The rebel invites everyone to join him in his war against the Capitol and to offer their lives just like him. I dont think the fact that the song accompanied the rebels in their greatest attack against the Capitol (during the first 3 movies), where so many people sacrificed their lives. This however could be countered by saying the lyrics were changed to "necklace of HOPE". Even though i read somewhere that the song is banned in Panem at least since Katniss was a little kid, so many people could know of its original lyrics. It has only been a week since i started watching the Hunger Games and i haven't read any of the books, so forgive me for any mistakes i have made and also for any grammar,syntax or spelling mistakes, since english is not my mother tongue. Thank you for your time and i hope for some answers to which i will happily response, Chris

The hanging tree is a symbol of oppression that's thousands of years old.. Â It's about the tyranny of the minority (the nobility) versus freedom/nationalism (the commoner).. For example, Christ was hanged from a tree. Â The most famous hanging tree was Tyburn (or hanging tree) in England. Â It was synonymous with capital punishment by power of the nobility without trial, it having been the principal place for execution of London criminals and convicted traitors, including many religious and political martyrs.The first recorded execution took place at a site next to the stream in 1196. William Fitz Osbert, the populist leader of the poor of London, was cornered in the church of St Mary le Bow. He was dragged naked behind a horse to Tyburn, where he was hanged. In 1537, Henry VIII used Tyburn to execute the ringleaders of the Pilgrimage of Grace, including Sir Nicholas Tempest, one of the northern leaders of the Pilgrimage and the King's own Bowbearer of the Forest of Bowland. His daughter Queen Mary burned her opponents at Tyburn. Â Later Tyburn was eulogized as a place of martyrs and freedom riders and thus moved to NewGate by the Hanovers, who kept their executions secret. Â Ida Wells used the aspect of the hanging tree in her famous essays on lynching of men/women of color. Â To narrow the scope of the hanging tree to just American slavery is an injustice to men and women all over the world who have fought against tyranny. Â Today, injustice plagues women in the Middle East; young men/women who struggle to secure a livelihood; and a host of tyranny be it political or religious (like ISIS), or a corrupt and self serving government.Â

+Vivian Brody I never said that.  So your argument is that if the lowest income earners aren't paying taxes, then the highest earners shouldn't either.  Good plan!  Also, yes I'm fairly sure they don't pay more taxes than the rich, because then they'd have to pay the entirety of their income and go in debt to pay the amount high income earners are paying in taxes, but % wise, they pay similarly. On the other hand, my point is, and this comes from someone who earns a lot of money, that higher income earners have much more discretionary income.  Most of my excess money goes towards making more money in property investments (which I then pay property taxes on, damn it) and other types of investments.  However, I don't need that to survive whatsoever. For those who don't owe any federal income tax at the end of the year, they sometimes aren't even making enough to cover necessities.  The only way they don't have to pay federal income tax is if they work and make less than $20K, or those who don't make any money at all.  However, those getting the EITC, still pay payroll, state, and muni taxes so there isn't a per se aspect.  THEY DO PAY TAXES.  They just don't have an extra $100K to pay those taxes with.  So for example, if I make $20K-payroll- $0tax, I have $20K-payroll tax in disposable income.  If I make $100K-payroll tax-$22,331(22.33% effective rate)=$77,669-payroll tax disposable income.  That is assuming single and no deductions which is very unlikely.  Assuming necessities cost $20K, then I've still got $57,669 for houses, electronics, boats, cars, and more.  What horrible punishments! I highly doubt you make $400K+ which is the only point at which you start really paying a higher rate that actually sways the effective rate, and there are plenty of deductions and ways around that with special dividend income taxes, etc.  While we're arguing about this, the rest of the world is kicking our butt in every per-capita economic metric.  What is your solution to taxes though really.  Even if you take all of the $20K earner's income, you're not getting as much in taxes as you would from the $100K earner.  Success doesn't mean you shouldn't have to pay taxes, but you still end up with much more money even after taxes.  I'll take that kind of punishment all day.  The sad thing is rich people tricked you into making these crazy arguments for them with Tea Party nonsense.  I truly pity you. TL;DR If you're paying tons in taxes, you're making tons, and you'll have tons left after taxes.

+Valvery Overlysimplifed, but succinct and accurate. The British were shocked that the Colonists reacted so badly to their taxes, because in their view the taxes were necessary and just to defray the expenses of fighting the various wars with France (which always spilled over into the Colonies). The colonists, however, figured that the overlying wars were not their concern, except insofar as they brought war to THEIR homes, at which point it was the RESPONSIBILITY of the British to protect them. Moreover, they felt they had done their part DURING said wars, fighting alongside the redcoats (and teaching them how to survive warfare in the New World). It was all a great, but inevitable misunderstanding. Fortunate, as well, because History would have been so much worse off without an independent United States of America.

The Hanging Tree (Marty Robbins song) The Hanging Tree is a western ballad from the 1959 movie The Hanging Tree. Hello all. I can't tag everyone who has replied or liked this comment so really whoever reads it will read it. When I found this song and my colleagues and I listened to it we all had different views on it. We decided to make it into a sociology experiment, one we could share with our students. I wrote a comment to sound as it it was written by a teenager and took a strong stand on the song (specifically the way it was sung) Ever since I have been collecting data weekly to see  how different people would anonymously react to this. I am going to use this data and these comments in a study write up, but all names, profiles, and times will not be included. Thank you all for being involved in the study. Ddarra Smith i posted my idea at a comment too, but i just read about your experiment and i thought it could be nice to write it here too. So, here it is: Well, this is my interpretation of the song. It may not be correct, but i am also writing this to discuss with other people and see what they think the song means. Some things i will state may be considered a given by some, but i would not feel good if i left them out. Sorry for the length of my comment... Â  ~At first the singer is like an observer to what happens. This can be identified by the use third person ("he murdered","he called out"). Later, first person is used and it's revealed the singer is the dead man. ~The audience is in my opinion the man's loved one. About the singer and its audience, i will say more later... ~It seems to me that the Hanging Tree is every place that people get hurt or even die while fighting against the Capitol. It could mean the whipping posts or execution stands but i think it's mostly about the rebellion (first or second?). Personally, i think the last four lines of each verse are reinforcing my opinion. "Strange things did happen here. No stranger would it be. If we met at midnight. In the hanging tree." Stranger things are the tortures and murders done by the Capitol. It wouldn't be stranger if the people turned against the Capitol and murdered some Peacekeepers too. ~By saying "Are you coming to the tree?", the singer invites its audience to come to the Tree. So, because the Tree is the rebellion, the dead man is every person that has stood against the Capitol. It makes more sense if we consider that every person that goes against the Capitol puts its life in danger (and is fully aware of it), so it is an already dead man. The loved one is every other person in the world that hasn't taken part in the rebellion (yet). Why loved one? I think it's a way to show the love among the districts' citizens. Each two of them are united, like two lovers, not just two ordinary people, but a couple with common needs, desires and goals. ~Midnight is the darkest time of a day (night actually...). It is also the time that most terrifying things (ghosts and such) are coming alive and a rebellion is terrifying for President Snow and its consequences would be dark for him. Last but not least, at midnight the day ends and a new one is coming, so if the lovers-citizens met they could bring an end to this dark era-day and give rise to a new era of peace and prosperity for everyone. The above are about the lyrics repeated in every verse. Now let me tell you my opinion about the rest. ~"Where they strung up a man. They say murdered three." So it's obvious the Capitol has killed a rebel. I can't but focus on "they say". The man probably hasn't done anything or at least anything against someone non-Capitol. He is accused of false things. The song indicates the rulers of Panem are killing innocent people. ~"Where the dead man. Called out for his love to flee." Most people would say that the dead man tried to save his loved one, telling her to run away. I will go against this and say that he tried to save her, by telling her to join the rebellion. This is the only way for her (remember the loved one is actually everyone!) to be saved. If she run away she would simply survive, but if she fought she would LIVE!!! ~"Where i told you to run. So we 'd both be free." It is just like the two lines i analyzed above, so please allow me to rest a little bit... ~"Wear a necklace of rope. Side by side with me." The rebel invites everyone to join him in his war against the Capitol and to offer their lives just like him. I dont think the fact that the song accompanied the rebels in their greatest attack against the Capitol (during the first 3 movies), where so many people sacrificed their lives. This however could be countered by saying the lyrics were changed to "necklace of HOPE". Even though i read somewhere that the song is banned in Panem at least since Katniss was a little kid, so many people could know of its original lyrics. It has only been a week since i started watching the Hunger Games and i haven't read any of the books, so forgive me for any mistakes i have made and also for any grammar,syntax or spelling mistakes, since english is not my mother tongue. Thank you for your time and i hope for some answers to which i will happily response, Chris

Chris Vazouras Since you've only watched the movies, you can say that that's what the song is about, but you kind of missed the point. (I would have done the same if I have never read the books) So that song has existed before the rebellion. It is a song from district 12, and Katniss'es father taught her it. As a kid, she never understood what the song was about, so she even made actual necklaces out of rope for her and Prim. But, when her mother saw that, she didn't allow them to sing that song anymore. She knew what it was about. It is when you love someone so much, that you don't want to see them get hurt anymore. You want them dead. Alongside with you. *SPOILERS* (Kind of) In the last book, the mockingjay, she wanted to kill Peta. Snow has hurt him, and she can't get over that. He doesn't know what is real, and what isn't, and he thinks Katniss is his biggest enemy and a liar. All his love for her is gone. ;( So, if you want to analize the song with that, here's what you get...  Are you, are you, coming to the tree. Are you comming to the place you last saw your loved one, are you comming to die with her (Katniss-to Peta) They strung up a man, they say who murdered three. Katniss feels dead. She is broken. She also thinks she's responsible for a lot of deaths that have happened. (Not going to spoil that for you) Strange thing did happen here, no stranger would it be. If we met, at midnight, in the Hanging Tree. Strange things are all the deaths, wars and tortures that have happened during the revolution, and she wants to, as I said, die, so it wouldn't be stranger with so many deaths that have already happened. Where the man called out, for his love to flee.  She wanted Peta to leave, before she could hurt him, befire anyone could hurt him. She wanted to leave him for good. But, as you know, he didn't. Where I told you too run, so we'd both be free, She told both Peta and Gale to run away with her (remember the first scene of the movie, where Gale asks her to run away, she suggests the same, in the 2nd book) Gale, however says no, while Peta says yes, because yet again, he loves her so much he'd risk his life for her (which he has done a couple of times). Wear a necklace of rope, side by side with me. At the end, Katniss is lost and broken, and hurt , and all she wants is to die, and she promises herself she would kill Peta first, to save him, for once.  Because she loves him And she feels in debt to him, that's why she always screamed she wants Peta to be safe. He saved her, and she wants to be even. But this time, because she trully loves him. Now, in the movie, they didn't make it so much of a love story, as they did make it a war and rebelion. So, from the movie point of view, you are correct. The only thing is that you forgot, the rebellion song had the lyrics Wear a necklace of hope, side by side with me.  So that the lyrics would match the rebellion.

For those of you who keep saying that this song is horrible based solely on the fact that you think Jennifer Lawrence can't sing are looking at this from the wrong perspective. This song isn't meant to impress people by her singing skills. The song is meant for the character in the movie, just like in the book. I highly doubt Lawrence said she wanted to sing a song for the soundtrack because she wants to start taking up a singing career. The fact that she sang the song is way more legit then having someone like Christina Aguilera sing the song for her. I think she did a fantastic job because you can hear the emotions in her voice as she sings. Which is to express what her character is feeling. So for her to be able to project those emotions in a song is awesome. Had the song been song with a perfect voice and belted out in different temples perfectly, the song wouldn't have the effect in the film that it has. As for the remix if you don't like it because you feel that she sucked as a singer then reread what I said above but if you don't like it because you think it was made by the Capitol then lol you guys are funny but if you didn't like it because you feel the meaning was lost, it's a movie guys and this isn't the first song from a movie to be turned into a remixed radio version.

The hanging tree is a symbol of oppression. Â It's about the tyranny of the minority (the nobility) versus freedom/nationalism (the commoner).. Â For many centuries, the name Tyburn (or hanging tree) was synonymous with capital punishment, it having been the principal place for execution of London criminals and convicted traitors, including many religious and political martyrs.The first recorded execution took place at a site next to the stream in 1196. William Fitz Osbert, the populist leader of the poor of London, was cornered in the church of St Mary le Bow. He was dragged naked behind a horse to Tyburn, where he was hanged. In 1537, Henry VIII used Tyburn to execute the ringleaders of the Pilgrimage of Grace, including Sir Nicholas Tempest, one of the northern leaders of the Pilgrimage and the King's own Bowbearer of the Forest of Bowland. His daughter Queen Mary burned her opponents at Tyburn. Â Later Tyburn was eulogized as a place of martyrs and freedom riders and thus moved to NewGate by the Hanovers, who kept their executions secret. Â Ida Wells used the aspect of the hanging tree in her famous essays on lynching of men/women of color. Â To narrow the scope of the hanging tree to just American slavery is an injustice to men and women all over the world who have fought against tyranny. Â Today, injustice plagues women in the Middle East; young men/women who struggle to secure a livelihood; and a host of tyranny be it political or religious (like ISIS). Â  Â Â
