Social Media TerroristÂ Correct! Â passage is "We didn't sing it anymore, my father and I, or even speak of it. After he died, it used to come back to me a lot. Being older, I began to understand the lyrics. At the beginning, it sounds like a guy is trying to get his girlfriend to secretly meet up with him at midnight. But it's an odd place for a tryst, a hanging tree, where a man was hung for murder. The murderer's lover must have had something to do with the killing, or maybe they were just going to punish her anyway, because his corpse called out for her to flee. That's weird obviously, the talking-corpse bit, but it's not until the third verse that "The Hanging Tree" begins to get unnerving. You realize the singer of the song is the dead murderer. He's still in the hanging tree. And even though he told his lover to flee, he keeps asking if she's coming to meet him. The phrase "Where I told you to run, so we'd both be free" is the most troubling because at first you think he's talking about when he told her to flee, presumably to safety. But then you wonder if he meant for her to run to him. To death. In the final stanza, it's clear that that's what he's waiting for. His lover, with her rope necklace, hanging dead next to him in the tree.

Social Media TerroristÂ Liberals are making it fit to Billy Holidays' Strange Fruit - but this is nonsense. Â Ida Wells referenced her texts on Tyburn. Period. Â The song Strange Fruit by Holiday was also a take on Tyburn and the Carte Blanche that the French Monarchs used to imprison or hang prisoners without benefit of trial (French Revolution). Â The people hung at Tyburn were called 'strange fruit". Â Daniel Boone, when he lived and acted as judge in Missouri held court in the front of his house which boasted a large hanging tree. Â He referred to the tree "offering fruit" to justice. Â

They changed the lyrics slightly to those in the book. In the fourth verse, Katniss sings "wear a necklace of HOPE side by side with me", in the book however, it's written asÂ "wear a necklace of ROPE side by side with me". The book even explains the meaning behind the lyrics: "... We didn't sing it anymore, my father and I, or even speak of it. After he died, it used to come back to me a lot. Being older, I began to understand the lyrics. At the beginning, it sounds like a guy is trying to get his girlfriend to secretly meet up with him at midnight. But it's an odd place for a tryst, a hanging tree, where a man was hung for murder. The murderer's lover must have had something to do with the killing, or maybe they were just going to punish her anyway, because his corpse called out for her to flee. That's weird obviously, the talking-corpse bit, but it's not until the third verse that "The Hanging Tree" begins to get unnerving. You realize the singer of the song is the dead murderer. He's still in the hanging tree. And even though he told his lover to flee, he keeps asking if she's coming to meet him. The phrase "Where I told you to run, so we'd both be free" is the most troubling because at first you think he's talking about when he told her to flee, presumably to safety. But then you wonder if he meant for her to run to him. To death. In the final stanza, it's clear that that's what he's waiting for. His lover, with her rope necklace, hanging dead next to him in the tree. ...I used to think the murderer was the creepiest guy imaginable. Now, with a couple of trips to the Hunger Games under my belt, I decide not to judge him without knowing more details. Maybe his lover was already sentenced to death and he was trying to make it easier. To let her know he'd be waiting. Or maybe he thought the place he was leaving her was really worse than death..."

When I first heard the Hanging Tree, I almost cried and my heart burst. The Hanging Tree signifies Katniss and Peeta's relationship and it also signifies hope in the darkness when the people of Panem rebel against the Capitol and President Snow. There's much more to the song. I think the song represents Christ hanging on a cross to die; and to redeem us from sin and darkness. When she says "Are you coming to the tree?", she is guiding us to the tree (the cross) (in Panem's case, the Hanging Tree and what Peeta had went through during his captivity in the Capitol.), someone who had died is calling her to the tree "Where I told you to run so we'd both be free"; signifies Christ's dying and resurrection from the dead
